Tuning(s): Standard/Common:  3-string: A3•A3•D3 4-string: A3 A3•A3•D3 5-string: A3 A3•A3•D3 D3 6-string: A3 A3•A3 A3•D3 D3  Alternates (see notes):  Mixolydian: D4•A3•D3 Dorian: G3•A3•D3 Aeolian: C4•A3•D3 Galax ("Unison"): D4•D4•D3
Alternative Names: Mountain Dulcimer, Appalachian Dulcimer, Lap Dulcimer, Dulcimore, Delcimore, Delcimer
Notes: Most dulcimers are either 3 or 4 course; any or all courses may be doubled with a second, unison string—hence the number of different stringing possibilities. Alternates listed here give a pitch for each whole course, regardless of number of strings. Many variants are used; there is no fixed "standard" for the four-course. Chromatic instruments exist, but traditionally dulcimers are fretted in diatonic intervals: whole (step), whole, half, whole, whole, whole, half.[12]

Tuning(s): Common*:  4-string: D4•D4•A3•D3 5-string: D4 D4•D4•A3•D3 6-string: D4 D4•D4•A3•D3 D3 8-string: D4 D4•D4 D4•A3 A3•D3 D3  Alternates (see notes):  G-tuning: D4•B3•G3•D3 Dorian: D4•C4•G3•D3 Ragtime: D4•A#3•A3•D3 D-tuning: F#4•D4•A3•D3
Alternative Names: Mountain Dulcimer, Appalachian Dulcimer, Lap Dulcimer, Dulcimore, Delcimore, Delcimer

Tuning(s): No standard; string is tuned to any convenient pitch.

Notes: Typically three fretted strings; three drones, but the number of drones may vary widely. Similar in concept to the Apalacian Dulcimer

Notes: [*] There is no "standard" tuning. One string is tuned to any convenient pitch, and the other is tuned one octave higher.

Tuning(s): Standard/common: G3 D4 A4 E5 Alternates:  Cajun: F3 C4 G4 D5 Open G: G3 D4 G4 B4 Sawmill: G3 D4 G4 D5 Gee-dad: G3 D4 A4 D5 Open D: D3 D4 A4 D5 High bass: A3 D4 A4 E5 Cross tuning: A3 E4 A4 E5 Calico: A3 E4 A4 C#5
Notes: "Fiddle" describes a playing style more than a unique instrument; a fiddle is just a violin with a slightly different "set-up". Standard AKA "Italian" or "orchestral" tuning, High Bass AKA "Old-time D tuning", Cross tuning AKA "High counter", Calico AKA "Black Mountain Rag" or the Swedish tunings: Trollstämning, or Näckastämning

Tuning(s): Standard: E2 A2 D3 G3 B3 E4 Common Alternates:  Drop D: D2 A2 D3 G3 B3 E4 Open D: D2 A2 D3 F#3 A3 D4 Open G: D2 G2 D2 G2 B3 D4 Open A: E2 A2 E3 A3 C#4 E4 Lute: E2 A2 D3 F#3 B3 E4 Irish: D2 A2 D3 G3 A3 D4 Nashville: E3 A3 D4 G4 B3 E4
Alternative Names: Classical guitar, 6-string guitar, Spanish guitar, Steel-string guitar
Notes: "classical" = guitar with gut, nylon, or other synthetic strings; "acoustic"/"steel-string" = guitar with metal strings; Open G AKA "bottleneck," "taro patch"; Open A AKA "Spanish"; "Lute tuing" is usually capoed on 3rd fret to give G2 C3 F3 A3 D4 G4, and E2 is often dropped to D2 (F2 with capo). There are hundreds of alternate guitar tunings; whole books have been written on the subject.[13]

Standard/Common: A3 D4 A4 E5 res. strings: (B3) D4 E4 F#4 A4 Common alternates:  Kolagutstille: A3 C4 A4 E5  res.: (A3) D4 E4 G4 A4  Seljekvatstille: A3 D4 F#4 E5  res.: (B3) D4 E4 F#4 A4  Trollstilt: A3 E4 A4 C#5  res.: (A3) C#4 E4 F#4 A4  Forstemt: A3 E4 A4 E5  res.: (A3) C#4 E4 F#4 A4  Gorrlaus: F3 D4 A4 E5  res.: (F3) B3 D4 G4 A4  Bas: G3 D4 A4 E5  res.: (B3) D4 E4 G4 A4
Notes: Standard AKA "Oppstilt bas" : More than 80% of music written for this instrument uses this tuning. Trollstilt AKA  "Devil's Tuning"  Bas AKA "Violin tuning"  There are many other variant tunings, most of them uncommon.

Tuning(s): Cb1 Db1 Eb1 Fb1 Gb1 Ab1 Bb1 [ . . . ] * Cb7 Db7 Eb7 Fb7 Gb7
Alternative Names: Pedal Harp, Double-action Harp, Diatonic Double-action Harp
Notes: * Only lowest and highest octaves shown. Tuning proceeds through 6-1/2 octaves using the Cb diatonic scale

Tuning(s): C2 D2 E2 F2 G2 A2 B2 [ . . . ] * C6 D6 E6 F6 G6 A6
Notes: * Number of strings varies, generally between 19-40; 34 strings is typical. Not all models have levers. Only lowest and highest octaves shown. Tuning proceeds through 4-1/2 octaves using the C diatonic scale.

Tuning(s): [*]Typical: C2 C#2 D2 D#2 E2 F2 F#2 G2 G#2 A2 A#2 B2 [...] * C#6 D6 D#6 E6 F6 F#6 G6 G#6 A6 A#6 B6 C7
Alternative Names: Virginal, Spinet, Clavicytherium, Ottavino, Pedal Harpsichord, et al
Notes: Many variants exist having differing number of keys, multiple keyboards, pedal boards, choirs of strings, etc., and they may have anywhere from about 120 to many hundreds of strings. Tuning is given for a typical single-keyboard, 5-octave instrument, for the main choir of strings. Only lowest and highest octaves are shown; intervening notes are tuned chromatically. Often tuning is in some musical temperament other than 12-tone equal temperament (common on modern pianos).

Tuning(s): GG • CC • EE • GG
G2 •D3 D4•G3 G3•B3 B3•E3
E2 A2 D3 G3
Traditional: (G4)G4 C4 G3 C3 C2 Alternates:  Altered Traditional:  (G4)G4 C4 G3 C3 G2  Bourbonnais:  (D5)D4 D4 G3 D3 D2  Altered Bourbonnais:  (D5)D4 D4 A3 D3 G2  Vendée:  (A5)A5 D4 A3 D3 D2
Alternative Names: Beggar’s lyre, Crank lyre, Cymphan, Forgolant, Organistrum, Symphonia, Wheel fiddle, Wheel vielle
Notes: Stringing is given in reverse order, owing to the orientation of the instrument while playing. The first one (or two) strings are melody strings; others are drone strings. Other regional tuning variants exist.

Tuning(s): no standard [*]
Notes: [*] string is tuned to any note convenient for the vocalist

Tuning(s): (E • B)
Notes: Pitch varies depending what other instruments the Igil is playing with, but the two strings are always tuned a 5th apart.

Tuning(s): Standard/Common: G3 G2•D4 D3•A3 A3•E4 E4 Alternates:  Mandolin:  G2 G2•D3 D3•A3 A3•E4 E4  Irish:  G3 G2•D4 D3•A3 A3•D4 D4  Modal D:  A3 A2•D4 D3•A3 A3•D4 D4
Alternative Names: Bouzouki, Octave Mandolin, Tenor Mandolin (US), Tenor Mandola (UK), Zouk
Notes: Irish bouzouki is an octave mandolin with the two lowest courses tuned in octaves instead of unisons. "Modal D" octaves can also be tuned in unisons.

Tuning(s): Modern or "Commercial"  A3 • D4 D4 • G3 G4 • B3 B3 • E4  Traditional  G3•C4 C4•E3 E3•A3 A3•G4
Notes: Part of their name usually describes their size, for example: Jarana Chaquiste, Jarana Primera, Jarana Segunda, Jarana Tercera, Jarana Tercerola Where octave doublings occur will often differ depending on the size of the instrument. The larger instruments commonly double the middle courses at the octave.

Tuning(s): Standard/Common: G2•A2•D2•G3 Alternates:  C2•D2•G2•C3 C2•D2•G3•C3 A2•D3•G3•C3
Alternative Names: Jarocha Requinto, Requinto Jarocha, Guitarra De Son

Tuning(s): D A E
Notes: Absolute pitch is not fixed on this instrument

Tuning(s): G • G • B B • D D
A#• B •C# •F• F#
Notes: Uses a gamelan pelog scale. Tuning is approximated to western notation.

Tuning(s): G4 G3•C4•D4 D3•A3•D4 D4
Notes: Strings/courses are usually 8/5 but 7/5, 9/5, 10/5 or 11/5 variations exist.

Tuning(s): B2 E2 A2 D3 F3 B3
Standard/Common: GG • DD • GG • CC Alternate: DD • AA • DD • GG
G3 A3 C3 D3 E3 F3 G4 A4 B4 C4 G3 A3 C3 D3 E3 F3 G4 A4 B♭4 C4
Notes: Since the 1980s the most common tunings for 11-stringed kokles among kokles players.

Tuning(s): A E A

Traditional Tunings:  Tomora Ba/Silaba: F2 C3 D3 E3 F3 G3 A3 B3 C4 D4 E4 F4 G4 A4 B4 C5 D5 E5 F5 G5 A5 Tomora Mesengo: F2 C3 +D3 +Eb3 F3 G3 +A3 +Bb3 C4 +D4 +Eb4 F4 G4 +A4 +Bb4 C5 +D5 +Eb5 F5 G5 +A5 Hardino: F2 C3 -D3 +E3 F3 G3 -A3 +B3 C4 -D4 +E4 F4 G4 -A4 +B4 C5 -D5 +E5 F5 G5 -A5 Sauta: F#2 C3 D3 E3 F#3 G3 A3 B3 C4 D4 E4 F#4 G4 A4 B4 C5 D5 E5 F#5 G5 A5
Notes: Scales roughly correspond to Western major, minor, and lydian scales, but are not in equal temperament. Any of the scales may be considered "standard".

Tuning(s): Traditional tunings:  Itsikotchu-chô:  D4 D4 A3 B3 D4 E4 F#4 A4 B4 D5 E5 F#5 A5  Oshiki-chô:  E4 A3 B3 D4 E3 F#3 A3 B3 C#4 E4 F#4 A4 B4  Sui-chô:  E4 A3 B3 C#4 E3 F#3 A3 B3 C#4 E4 F#4 A4 B4  Hyô-jô:  B3 E3 F#3 A3 B3 C#4/D4 E4 F#4 A4 B4 C#5/D5 E5 F#5  Taishiki-chô:  B3 E3 F#3 G#3 B3 C#4 E4 F#4 G#4 B4 C#4 E4 F#4  Banskiki-chô:  F#3 B3 C#3 E3 F#3 G#3/A3 B3 C#4 E4 F#4 G#4/A4 B4 C#5  Sôjô:  G3 G3 D3 E3 G3 A3 B3 D4 E4 G4 A4 B4 D5
Notes: Tuning depends on the piece being played. A4 is closer to 430 Hz than to the western standard (440 Hz), and intervals are in just intonation and not equal temperament. In some tunings alternate choices are available for strings 6 and 11 (indicated with a slash); whatever note is chosen these strings are always tuned one octave apart.

Tuning(s): GG • EE • AA • DD

Notes: Standard a.k.a. "Mainland"

Notes: Same tuning as the Octavina

Tuning(s): G3 G4 • C3 C4 • E4 E4 • A4 A4

Tuning(s): Standard/Common: C3 • F3 • C4 • G4 • C5 Alternate:  Hu ai Cam: G2 • D3 • G3 • B4 • D5  (a.k.a. "slide guitar tuning")
Alternative Names: Đàn Ghita, Ghita, Phím Lõm, Vietnamese guitar
Notes: Originally a 4- or 5-string instrument; today often nearly identical to a 6-string western guitar, except for having a scalloped fingerboard and one less string. (See below.)

Tuning(s): Standard/Common: E2 • A2 • D3 • G3 • B4 • E4 Alternates:  Day Rach-Gia: E2 • A2 • D3 • G3 • D4 • G4 Day Lai: D2 • A2 • D3 • G3 • D4 • G4 Day Sai Gon: D2 • G2 • D3 • G3 • D4 • G4

Notes: "Standard" identical with the common western guitar. Day Lai a.k.a. "aculturated tuning" Day Sai Gon a.k.a. "Saigon Tuning"

Tuning(s): Medieval 12 string/6 course:  G2 G2 • C3 C3 • F3 F3 • A3 A3 • D4 D4 • G4 G4  Medieval 13 string/7 course:  D2 D3•G2 G3•C3 C4•F3 F3•A3 A3•D4 D4•G4  Renaissance 15 string/8 course  D2 D3•F2 F3•G2 G3•C3 C4•F3 F3•A3 A3•D4 D4•G4  Renaissance 19 string/10 course  C2 C3•D2 D3•E♭2 E♭3•F2 F3•G2 G3•C3 C4•F3 F3•A3 A3•D4 D4•G4  Baroque 24 string/13 course  A1 A2•B1 B2•C2 C3•D2 D3•E2 E3•F2 F3•G2 G3•A2 A2•D3 D3•F3 F3•A3 A3•d4•f4
Notes: [ * ] The number of strings and courses on a lute can vary widely depending on period and geographical region. Among the more common forms are 6, 7, 8, 10, and 13 courses. (Pictured: 8 course Renaissance Lute.)

Tuning(s): Standard/Common: E1 A1 D2 G2 Alternate: G1 D2 A2 E3
Notes: The alternate tuning (2 octaves below the mandolin) is usually applied to a smaller-scale instrument (see Mandobass).

Tuning(s): Standard/Common: G1 G1•D2 D2•A2 A2•E3 E3 Alternate:  "Mandola": C1 C1•G1 G1•D2 D2•A2 A2
Notes: Relatively rare; larger than the standard mandobass. Standard tuning is 2 octaves below the mandolin.

Notes: Standard tuning is 1 octave below the mandola.

Tuning(s): C3 C3•G3 G3•D4 D4•A4 A4

Notes: Standard instrument of the mandolin family.

Tuning(s): G3 G3•D4 D4•A4 A4•E5 E5

Notes: Tuned a 4th above the mandolin; 1 octave above the mandola.

Notes: A member of the viol family. A rare 6-string version adds a G3 below the low C string.

Tuning(s): Standard/Common:  E9th: B2 D3 E3 F#3 G#3 B3 E4 G#4 D#4 F#4 C6th: C2 F2 A2 C3 E3 G3 A3 C4 E4 D4  Alternates:  A7th: A1 E2 G2 A2 C#3 E3 G3 A3 C#4 E4 C Diatonic: G2 A2 C3 E3 F3 G3 A3 B3 C4 E4
Notes: [ * ] 10 strings is more or less standard now, but instruments with 6, 8, 12, and other numbers of strings, and 2, 3, or 4 necks exist. A different tuning is usually applied to each neck, but setups vary from player to player.

Tuning(s): A3 E4 A4

Alternative Names: Pianoforte, Grand, Grand Piano, Concert Grand, Upright, Upright Piano, Spinet
Notes: * About 2/3 of courses are triple strung; some lower courses are double strung; the remaining bases are single strung. All multi-strung courses are tuned to unisons. Exact number of strings varies by manufacturer and model, 220 - 240 is typical.[14] Only lowest and highest octaves are shown; tuning of the intervening notes is chromatic.

* About 2/3 of courses are triple strung; some lower courses are double strung; the remaining bases are single strung. All multi-strung courses are tuned to unisons. Only lowest and highest octaves are shown; tuning of the intervening notes is chromatic. These extended-range pianos are very expensive and uncommon.

Tuning(s): A2 D3 E3 A3

Tuning(s): A2 D3 G3 C4 E4 A4
Notes: 4th above the standard guitar

Tuning(s): Standard Argentine (G6/Em7): D4 D4•G4 G4•B4 B3•E4 E4•B4 B4 Standard Bolivian (F6/Dm7): C4 C4•F4 F4•A4 A3•D4 D4•A4 A4 Standard Chilean (C6/Am7): G3 G3•C4 C4•E4 E3•A3 A3•E4 E4 Common Variants: [*]  G4 G3•C5 C4•E4 E3•A3 A3•E4 E4 G4 G3•C5 C4•E3 E3•A3 A3•E4 E4
Notes: [*] Instrument is still new enough that no one "standard" tuning has emerged. Chilean tuning (also a variant in Bolivia), one octave below the charango, is very common. Chilan variants (various octave doublings on courses 3, 4, and 5) depend on stringing—thinner strings are required for the high octaves in doubled courses. Argentine G6/Em7 tuning is also popular, which basically raises the pitch to that of the charangón.

Tuning(s): E2 A2 D3 G3
Notes: Same as bottom four strings of the guitar. A relatively new instrument; unlike the UBass (see below) it has sufficient volume to be played acoustically, and sounds more like a uke than a bass.

Tuning(s): E1 A1 D2 G2
Alternative Names: Bass Uke, Contrabass Ukulele, Rubber Bass, Travel Bass, U-Bass
Notes: Same as bass guitar. A relatively new instrument that has to be amplified to be heard; tone is much like a double bass. Compared to the acoustic bass uke (see above), this is really a contrabass instrument.

Tuning(s): Standard/Common: G4 C4 E4 A4 Alternate:  D6: A4 D4 F#4 B4
Notes: Often just a soprano uke with a slightly longer neck—15, 16 or 18 frets, as opposed to 12 or 13 frets.

Notes: Relatively recent: a miniature ukulele

Tuning(s): Standard/Common: G4 C4 E4 A4 Alternate (traditional):  D6: A4 D4 F#4 B4
Notes: The standard, basic ukulele. Traditionally, D6 tuning was used though C6 tuning is now most common.

Tuning(s): G4 G4 • C5 C5 • E5 E5 • A4 A4
Alternative Names: Tahitian banjo, Tahitian Ukulele, Ukulélé Tahitien, Youke

Notes: 5-, 6- and 8- string versions exist: 5-string has 4th (lowest)) course doubled; 6-string has 1st (highest) and 3rd courses doubled (see Taropatch); 8-string has all 4 courses doubled (see Lili'u)
Pitches are approximate: does not use the western equal tempered tuning system.
This is the modern Mariachi instrument. Vihuela also refers to many historic antecedents of the guitar, in various configurations, most of them currently obsolete.

Tuning(s): Standard/Common: G2 D3 A3 E4 Alternate:  F2 C3 G3 D4
Notes: Standard is one octave below the violin; 4th below the viola. Rare.

Tuning(s): *Bolivian (F6): C5 C5•F5 F5•A5 A4•D5 D5•A5 A5  Argentine (G6):  D5 D5•G5 G5•B5 B4•E5 E5•B5 B5
Notes: A soprano charango F6 = 4th higher than the charango G6 = 5th higher than the charango

Tuning(s): Standard/Common: A2 • E3 E3•A3 A3•C#4 C#4•E4 E4
Standard/Common: G3 • D4 D4•G4 G4•B4 B4•D5 D5
Standard/Common: C2 C2•G3 G3 G3•C4 C4 C4•E4 E4 E4•G4 G4 G4
Notes: Very rare, and possibly obsolete

Tuning(s): Standard/Common: C4 • G4 G4•C5 C5•E5 E5•G5 G5 Alternates:  D tuning: D4 • A4 A4•D5 D5•F#5 F#5•A5 A5
Standard/Common: C3 • G3 G3•C4 C4•E4 E4•G4 G4 Alternates:  D tuning: D3 • A3 A3•D4 D4•F#4 F#4•A4 A4 Open G major: G2 • D3 D3•G3 G3•B3 B3•D4 D4
Notes: The tenor is the standard waldzither; several other, less common tunings are also used[15]
Only lowest and highest octaves are shown; tuning of the intervening notes is chromatic. Rare.

Tuning(s): D3 A3 D4 A4'
Notes: lit. "small Ruan"

Tuning(s): See Nigenkin
D2 D2•A2 A2•D3 D3

Alternative Names: Yueh qin, Yueh chin, Moon guitar

Tuning(s): D3•A4
Alternative Names: Hengchun yueqin, Yueh qin, Yueh chin, Moon guitar

Tuning(s): Common: C2 D2 E2 G2 A2 C3 D4 E4 G4 A4 C4 D4 E4 G4 A4 C5 D5 E5
Notes: Tuning is not absolute, and is not limited by Western equal temperament. Zhengs also come with varying numbers of strings, typically from 16-26; the pentatonic tuning is extended to accommodate these extra (high and low) strings.

Tuning(s): G3 D4 A3 E4
Notes: Either tuning may be considered "standard".

Tuning(s): Standard/Common: G2 D3 G3 D4 Alternates:  G2 D3 A3 E4 (Mandolin) A2 E3 A3 E4
Notes: lit. "medium Ruan"; This is the standard/most common instrument of the five-member ruan family.

Strings & Courses: 5 fretted strings[*] 5 courses plus 37 open accompaniment & bass strings
Tuning(s): Fretted Strings Standard/Common: A4 A4 D4 G3 C3 Alternate:  Vienna: A4 D4 G3 G3 C3  [See ZITHER TUNING CHART, below, for unfretted string tunings]
Notes: Standard Tuning AKA "Munich" [*]  5 fretted melody strings 12 unfretted accompaniment strings 12 unfretted bass strings 13 unfretted contrabass strings

Strings & Courses: 5 fretted strings[*] 5 courses plus 29 - 30 open accompaniment & bass strings
Tuning(s): Fretted Strings Standard/Common: A4 A4 D4 G3 C3 Alternate:  Vienna: A4 D4 G3 G3 C3  [See ZITHER TUNING CHART, below, for unfretted string tunings]
Notes: Standard AKA "Munich" [*]  5 fretted melody strings 12 unfretted accompaniment strings 12 unfretted bass strings up to 13 unfretted contrabass strings (5 or 6 is the most common)

Tuning(s): Varied open string chord sets and chromatic or diatonic tuning of additional open strings. The string tuning is often printed on the instrument itself. See the picture. No frets nor fingerboard.
Alternative Names: Guitar zither, Chord zither, Fretless Zither
Notes: May have from 12 to 50 strings, or more, depending on design  See also Autoharp which has diatonic and chromatic open strings, and a stop mechanism to produce chords.
